awd_titl_txt: Dielectric Loss Processes and Microwave Effects on Reactions in Homogeneous Solutions
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Albert E. Stiegman at Florida State University and Professor Gregory B. Dudley at West Virginia University are developing a better fundamental understanding of how microwave heating can impact dynamic chemical processes. The discovery that microwave energy can create heat within a system has had profound impacts on society, but only in the last few decades has this technology found tactical use in organic chemistry. The long-term goal of this project is to harness microwave energy strategically to expand the capabilities of organic chemistry. This multidisciplinary project lies at the interface of chemical reaction kinetics, thermodynamics, and chemical synthesis. It provides excellent education and training for students from diverse backgrounds, including those from under-represented groups, to enter a dynamic and multidisciplinary workforce in the global innovation-based economy. An emphasis is being placed on widespread dissemination of emerging theories of microwave dielectric heating through online tutorial websites, scientific workshops, and perspective articles aimed at helping the research community with the strategic application of microwave heating in organic chemistry.

Microwave dielectric heating is known to enable volumetric heating of homogeneous systems and selective heating of heterogeneous systems, but selective heating of multicomponent solutions is not well documented. The planned experiments are expected to demonstrate that: (1) selective heating can perturb thermal equilibrium in multicomponent solution, (2) perturbation of thermal equilibrium produces chemical dynamics and reactivity patterns that cannot be produced with convective heating, and (3) solutions that are amenable to selective heating can be rationally designed and optimized. The proposed research efforts could advance knowledge and understanding of chemical dynamics under microwave dielectric heating, including how they differ from convective heat-transfer processes. Selective heating in multicomponent solution can have profound impacts on synthetic chemistry, including fine-chemical synthesis, catalysis, green chemistry, flow chemistry, etc.

por.por_cntn:
This project provided insights into selective microwave heating of organic reaction mixtures. What was once broadly dismissed as impossible is now validated, modeled, and rationalized, laying a foundation for future applications.

Soon after kitchen microwave ovens became widespread, organic chemists began experimenting with microwave heating of organic reaction mixtures. Early experiments were unpredictable and often surprising, leading some to postulate ill-defined "microwave effects", which were later dismissed as artefacts of poor temperature control. As microwave reactor technology advanced and control over reaction conditions improved, examples of surprising reactivity under microwave heating became less common, and those that persisted were often overlooked, disregarded, or dismissed.

We formulated a central design hypothesis that microwave energy can heat polar solutes selectively in otherwise microwave-transparent systems, and as the foundation for this project, we validated this hypothesis in simple initial systems to produce chemical dynamics that cannot be reproduced with convective heating. In particular, we used microwave heating to accelerate organic reactions beyond what would be predicted using traditional Arrhenius kinetic reaction theory, which is based on the measured solution temperature.

During the course of this project, we identified and developed a model in which the polar solutes agglomerate (gather together) in nonpolar solvent to form nanoscopic domains that are subject to selective heating. We observed these domains by small-angle neutron scattering, measuring their volume to be on the order of ~1 attoliter (10-18 L). We calculated the molecular temperatures of the polar and nonpolar solutes independently (using in situ Raman spectroscopy), concluding that the polar agglomerates were as much as 100 degC (180 degF) hotter than the bulk solution. We then postulated -- consistent with modeling simulations -- that these superheated agglomerates vaporize the surrounding solvent to produce an insulating vapor barrier, which traps heat inside the agglomerate, resulting in persistent temperature differentials on the order of minutes, even after the microwave energy source is turned off. 

We used this evolving understanding to design and test new reaction systems with the aim of quantifying the impact of selective microwave heating of kinetic reactivity. Those that reproducibly showed accelerated reactio kinetics were quantified and published. We observed and reported subtle concentration and solvent viscosity effects that are unique to microwave heating to support future designs. The last of these examples, published in 2022, highlighted a breakthrough observation that would have been difficult to anticipate at the outset of the project: selective microwave heating of a nonpolar, microwave-transparent substrate. We rationalized this latter observation by postulating incorporation of nonpolar solutes into an agglomeration of other polar solutes, such that thermal energy generated and trapped within the domain would drive chemical reactivity. 

With outcomes of both measuring parameters associated with selective heating and demonstrating its impact on organic reactions, this project laid a foundation for better strategic use of microwave heating in chemical reaction processes.
